questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of blurred vision upon awakening. When she wakes up in the morning, both eyelids are irritated, sore, and covered with a dry crust. Her symptoms improve after she takes a hot shower. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She does not wear contact lenses. Recently, she became sexually active with a new male partner. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F). Both eyes show erythema and irritation at the superior lid margin, and there are flakes at the base of the lashes. There is no discharge. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Triamcinolone, a topical glucocorticoid, is an agent of last resort for treating severe, treatment-refractory blepharitis. Topical steroids should be used carefully in this situation given the side effect profile, and patients should be evaluated by an ophthalmologist prior to initiation. This patient has a mild presentation and so a different management approach is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Culture and gram stain can be useful in diagnosing gonococcal conjunctivitis. While this patient has some risk factors (new sexual partner), gonococcal conjunctivitis is characterized by acute conjunctival hyperemia, purulent discharge, and periorbital swelling. Her symptoms are not consistent with gonococcal infection and a culture would not be helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline can be used in the treatment of severe or treatment-refractory blepharitis. It is not used as first-line treatment, especially for a mild presentation such as this one, because of the risk of adverse events, such as photosensitivity, gastrointestinal distress, and interference with oral contraceptives.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin can be helpful in the treatment of severe or treatment-refractory blepharitis, or in the perioperative period for patients undergoing eye surgery. It is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that reduces the bacterial load around the eyelids, lashes, and conjunctiva. However, it is not an appropriate first-line therapy for mild blepharitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin, a topical antibiotic, can be used to treat superficial community-acquired methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infections. While Staphylococcus is commonly implicated in blepharitis, this patient has a mild presentation and so a different management approach is more appropriate.

F) CORRECT:

Warm compresses, lid massage, and gentle lid cleansing are the cornerstones of therapy for mild blepharitis. As blepharitis is often a chronic condition with discrete episodes, ongoing lid hygiene is important in minimizing the frequency and intensity of flares.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography

There is crusting at the base of the eyelashes and the lid margin appears injected.

This is the typical appearance of blepharitis.
questions.hint: Chronic inflammation and scaling at the eyelid margins associated with eye irritation and visual abnormalities is consistent with a diagnosis of blepharitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless, slowly enlarging nodule on his left eyelid. He reports heaviness of the eyelid and blurred vision in his left eye. Treatment with warm compresses has not resulted in improvement. One year prior, he had a similar lesion on his left eyelid that was treated with incision and curettage. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a solitary, rubbery, nontender nodule on the central portion of the left upper eyelid. The lesion is better visualized on eversion of the eyelid. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maintaining eyelid hygiene with bactericidal and antiinflammatory lid cleansers (e.g., hypochlorous acid solution) can help resolve the first episode of a chalazion and prevent bacterial superinfection. This patient's skin lesion, however, is recurrent and has not improved with conservative treatment (e.g., warm compression).

B) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is used for the treatment of a number of skin lesions that can manifest as recurrent, painless skin nodules (e.g., molluscum contagiosum, basal cell carcinoma, sebaceous carcinoma). Unlike this patient's skin lesion, molluscum contagiosum typically manifests with pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. Moreover, the diagnosis must be established prior to cryotherapy of a malignant eyelid tumor.
Image Description:

Right eye

Several papules (green overlay) with central umbilication are visible on the eyelid and in the periocular region. Conjunctival injection is also present.

These findings are consistent with molluscum contagiosum with concurrent conjunctivitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are used to treat a hordeolum or bacterial superinfection of a chalazion, both of which can manifest with an eyelid nodule. Unlike the lesion seen here, these lesions are typically painful, erythematous, and purulent.
Image Description:

Right eye

There is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.

This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

D) CORRECT:

A recurrent or persistent nodule on the eyelid may indicate an underlying malignancy that is masquerading as a benign chalazion. Sebaceous carcinoma of the eyelid is a rare malignancy, which usually manifests as a hard nodule on the eyelid that resembles a recurrent or persistent chalazion. Basal cell carcinoma (most common eyelid tumor) often manifests as a papule with rolled-up pearly borders while squamous cell carcinoma (second most common eyelid tumor) manifests as a small nonhealing ulcer with rolled-up borders. Untreated, these tumors can metastasize and/or invade surrounding structures, including the intracranial cavity. Hence, timely diagnosis with a biopsy of the lesion for histopathological examination is recommended in all recurrent chalazia or those that do not respond to treatment.
Image Description:

Left eye with ectropionized lower eyelid

A localized, nodular swelling is visible on the medial portion of the ectropionized lower eyelid. Both bulbar and tarsal conjunctiva are hyperemic.

This is the typical appearance of a chalazion.

E) INCORRECT:

Watchful waiting can be considered in a patient presenting with a first episode of a chalazion, as some lesions resolve spontaneously. This patient, however, presents with a recurrent skin lesion that does not improve with conservative treatment (i.e., warm compressions) or invasive treatment (i.e., incision and curettage).

F) INCORRECT:

Mohs micrographic surgery is used for the excision of invasive tumors of the face (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, sebaceous carcinoma). Diagnosis of a malignant eyelid tumor must be established prior to surgical treatment; the cause of this patient's lesion, however, is unclear.
Image Description:

A pink multinodular lesion with central indentation is visible adjacent to the medial canthus of the left eye and the lower eyelid. Dried crusts can be seen on the surface of the lesion, suggesting ulceration.

This is the typical appearance of nodular basal cell carcinoma.
questions.hint: Although a painless nodule that is better seen on eversion of the eyelid is characteristic of a chalazion (an obstructed and enlarged meibomian gland), this patient's recurrent, unilateral eyelid lesion should raise concern for a different underlying condition.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of pain and swelling in her right eye. She has not had any visual changes. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms consistently. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the right eye is shown. The right eyelid is mildly tender on palpation. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics, such as gentamicin, can be considered in patients with frequent hordeola or severe symptoms (e.g., concurrent blepharoconjunctivitis), neither of which are reported here. Therefore, a different, first-line treatment should be tried in this patient before considering topical antibiotics.

B) CORRECT:

A hordeolum is an acute purulent inflammation of the eyelid, most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus, that occurs in two forms. This patient has an internal hordeolum, which typically arises at the palpebral conjunctiva. External hordeolum is more common and typically arises at the lid margin. For both types of hordeolum, the first step in management is the application of warm compresses and gentle massage to promote drainage of the blocked gland. Additionally, eyelid margin hygiene (i.e., debris removal with a clean cotton swab) should be maintained. If the patient has severe symptoms or does not respond to conservative treatment after 1–2 weeks, an ophthalmologist should be consulted for incision and curettage and antibiotic treatment (e.g., topical gentamicin, systemic cephalexin).

C) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy is performed in cases of recurrent or persistent chalazion to rule out malignancy (e.g., sebaceous carcinoma). Although chalazia can resemble hordeola in appearance, they are slow-growing and not associated with signs of inflammation (e.g., erythema, pain). This patient's clinical presentation is diagnostic of a hordeolum; therefore, there is no indication for an excisional biopsy.
Image Description:

Left eye with ectropionized lower eyelid

A localized, nodular swelling is visible on the medial portion of the ectropionized lower eyelid. Both bulbar and tarsal conjunctiva are hyperemic.

This is the typical appearance of a chalazion.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage can be used in the treatment of hordeolum manifesting with severe symptoms (e.g., large hordeolum) or not showing any response to medical management within 1–2 weeks of therapy. As this patient presents with mild symptoms for 1 day only, a different, first-line treatment should be tried before considering incision and drainage.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhea. Although neisserial conjunctivitis is seen in young, sexually active adults, like this patient, the presentation is usually more severe with marked eyelid swelling, profuse purulent discharge, and hyperemic conjunctiva, none of which are seen here. Systemic antibiotic therapy (e.g., oral cephalexin) may be indicated in persistent or severe hordeolum associated with complications (e.g., preseptal cellulitis) if conservative measures have been exhausted.
questions.hint: An acute, painful, erythematous nodule of the eyelid, in conjunction with this patient's otherwise unremarkable clinical presentation, is consistent with hordeolum (stye).

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents with a one-week history of burning, itching eyes, and the feeling of foreign-body irritation. Her symptoms worsen with dry weather. She feels well otherwise and reports no recent illness. She has a history of recurrent chalazia on the upper eyelids. On examination, visual acuity is 20/20 in each eye.
What examination finding would support the patient’s most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injected scleral vessels are a sign of scleritis, which is typically characterized by unilateral achy pain with tenderness to the touch.

B) INCORRECT:

Conjunctival follicles are pale, dome-shaped elevations of conjunctiva most commonly caused by infections, particularly with adenoviruses (pink eye).

C) INCORRECT:

A corneal epithelial defect is a corneal abrasion, which usually has a precipitating factor, such as trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Ciliary flush is characteristic of anterior uveitis, in which patients also have symptoms of photophobia and achy pain due to inflammation within the iris and ciliary body.

E) CORRECT:

The combination of ocular-surface symptoms (foreign-body sensation and burning) and recurrent chalazia is suggestive of blepharitis (chronic inflammation of the eyelids). Typical eye findings with this condition include crusting at the base of the eyelashes and ocular injection. Blepharitis can range from asymptomatic to severe, with symptoms including burning, itching, foreign-body sensation, dryness, and mucous discharge. Chronic inflammation may lead to obstruction of the oil glands causing a stye or chalazion. Blepharitis is treated with warm compresses, eyelid scrubs with baby shampoo, and preservative-free artificial tears.

Key learning point: In addition to inflammation of the eyelids, a classic feature of blepharitis is crusting of the eyelashes.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man describes intermittent ocular itching and burning for the past 6 months, with crusting of his eyelids in the morning. His medical history includes hypertension, rosacea, and type 2 diabetes, which is controlled with metformin.
On examination, his visual acuity is 20/25 in each eye. His eyes appear slightly injected but otherwise look normal. Close inspection of his eyelids shows slightly erythematous lid margins and flaky material at the base of the eyelashes.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Blepharitis, which refers to inflammation of the eyelid margin, causes ocular symptoms of itching, tearing, burning, and crusting. It usually affects both eyes and is typically chronic. It is associated with rosacea and results from poor glandular flow and build-up of bacteria, especially Staphylococcus, around the eyelids. Demodex infestation can also be associated with chronic blepharitis. Treatment for blepharitis consists of warm compresses, artificial tears, and lid scrubs with baby shampoo. Use of topical or oral antibiotics should be considered if the condition is associated with Staphylococcus or Demodex infection or with rosacea.

Key learning point: Chronic itching, burning, foreign-body sensation, crusting, and redness of the eyes are characteristic of blepharitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior uveitis typically manifests with a unilateral red eye, pain, and prominent photosensitivity.

C) INCORRECT:

A chalazion is a small sebaceous cyst of the eyelid that occurs when a meibomian gland is blocked. Patients with chalazia usually present with a short history of recent lid discomfort, followed by acute inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral conjunctivitis is characterized by itching, foreign-body sensation, and morning crusting of the lids, with redness. However, the discharge is often more exuberant than that seen in blepharitis, and symptoms typically start in one eye, spread to the other within a few days, and resolve spontaneously within 2 weeks.

E) INCORRECT:

Corneal abrasions are typically characterized by pain and foreign-body sensation that is more acute and intense than that seen with blepharitis.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with a bump on his right lower eyelid (figure). It has been visible to him for 3 months and has not changed in size recently. He does not have any discharge, severe eyelid pain, or decreased vision but notes some eye irritation.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hordeolum represents an acute inflammation and infection of a meibomian gland at the lid margin. It appears as a red, tender bump that may spontaneously leak purulent discharge. If unresolved, an acute internal hordeolum can become chronic or develop into a chalazion. Chalazia and hordeola are both treated with warm compresses to encourage drainage of the obstructed gland. Topical antibiotics may also be used.

B) INCORRECT:

Sebaceous carcinomas and basal-cell carcinomas of the eyelid appear as firm, painless masses on the eyelid. Unlike chalazia, sebaceous carcinomas tend to be indurated or ulcerated; basal-cell carcinomas tend to have surface telangiectasias and an irregular surface texture.

C) INCORRECT:

Sebaceous carcinomas and basal-cell carcinomas of the eyelid appear as firm, painless masses on the eyelid. Unlike chalazia, sebaceous carcinomas tend to be indurated or ulcerated; basal-cell carcinomas tend to have surface telangiectasias and an irregular surface texture.

D) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum of the eyelid is characterized by multiple small, dome-shaped nodules, with umbilicated centers, located at the eyelid margin.

E) CORRECT:

A chalazion is a lipogranuloma resulting from a chronically obstructed meibomian gland. It appears as a subacute, usually nontender mass that is minimally erythematous and initially infected. In contrast, a hordeolum represents an acute inflammation and infection of a meibomian gland at the lid margin. It appears as a red, tender bump that may spontaneously leak purulent discharge. If unresolved, an acute internal hordeolum can become chronic or develop into a chalazion.

Chalazia and hordeola are both treated with warm compresses to encourage drainage of the obstructed gland. Topical antibiotics may also be used. Chalazia that do not resolve with conservative therapy can be injected with glucocorticoids or surgically excised.

Key learning point: A subacute, nontender eyelid mass that results from a chronically inflamed meibomian gland is a chalazion.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy presents for evaluation of a painful bump that has been present on his left lower eyelid since yesterday. His mother reports that he has had no trauma, fever, or drainage from the area and has no history of a similar condition.
On examination, the patient is afebrile and appears well. A 2-mm, erythematous, tender mass is evident on the left lower eyelid (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Order antinuclear antibody and C-reactive protein testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although systemic lupus erythematosus and other rheumatologic diseases are associated with a host of ocular issues from dry eye to episcleritis to keratitis, a simple hordeolum should not prompt rheumatologic workup, including antinuclear antibody and C-reactive protein testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections around the eye can be serious and require prompt treatment with acyclovir and referral to an ophthalmologist. Affected patients typically experience symptoms such as eye pain, blurred vision or photophobia, and discharge. The eye itself is typically red. Although vesicular lesions in the distribution of the first branch of the trigeminal nerve (V1) should prompt evaluation of the eye for HSV ocular disease, typically there would be multiple lesions rather than a single lesion isolated to the lid as in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Hordeola can mimic periorbital cellulitis due to the inflammation, but they are typically localized and do not spread. Hordeola can increase the risk for developing cellulitis, in which case the first-line treatment would be amoxicillin-clavulanate. This patient’s erythema is localized to the swollen meibomian gland, with no evidence of cellulitis in the immediate surrounding periorbital area.

D) INCORRECT:

Chalazia are similar to hordeola but are typically less inflamed and are often painless, caused by obstruction of the gland without as much inflammation. Persistent chalazia that do not resolve after several months may be treated with surgical curettage or, if they are very large, more-extensive excision.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has an internal hordeolum with swelling of the internal aspect of the lower eyelid. Hordeola occur when the meibomian gland becomes inflamed. When a bacterial cause is identified, it is most commonly Staphylococcus aureus, but hordeola do not require treatment with antibiotics.

No specific intervention has been shown to be most effective in treating hordeola. The most common recommendation for supportive care is to apply a warm compress to the eyelid to soften the granulomatous tissue, leading to drainage of the pustule of the hordeolum, and to use gentle eyelid scrubs.

Antibiotic eye ointment is not indicated as initial therapy for hordeola; it can be used if a warm compress fails and there is evidence of secondary bacterial infection. If an internal hordeolum spreads and develops into preseptal cellulitis, oral antibiotics are indicated.

Key learning point: Hordeolum is a common, painful eyelid condition that is typically caused by infection with Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman has a 3-month history of blurred vision upon awakening. When she wakes up in the morning, both eyelids are irritated, sore, and covered with a dry crust. Both eyes show erythema and irritation at the superior lid margin, and there are flakes at the base of the lashes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A topical glucocorticoid, such as triamcinolone, is used as an agent of last resort for treating severe, treatment-refractory blepharitis. Topical steroids should be used carefully in this situation given the side effect profile, and patients should be evaluated by an ophthalmologist prior to initiation. This patient has a mild presentation and so a different management approach is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Culture and gram stain can be useful in diagnosing gonococcal conjunctivitis. Gonococcal conjunctivitis is characterized by acute conjunctival hyperemia, purulent discharge, and periorbital swelling. Her symptoms are not consistent with gonococcal infection and a culture would not be helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics, such as doxycycline, can be used in the treatment of severe or treatment-refractory blepharitis. It is not used as first-line treatment, especially for a mild presentation such as this one, because of the risk of adverse events, such as photosensitivity, gastrointestinal distress, and interference with oral contraceptives.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin can be helpful in the treatment of severe or treatment-refractory blepharitis, or in the perioperative period for patients undergoing eye surgery. It is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that reduces the bacterial load around the eyelids, lashes, and conjunctiva. However, it is not an appropriate first-line therapy for mild blepharitis.

E) CORRECT:

Warm compresses, lid massage, and gentle lid cleansing are the cornerstones of therapy for mild blepharitis. As blepharitis is often a chronic condition with discrete episodes, ongoing lid hygiene is important in minimizing the frequency and intensity of flares.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography

There is crusting at the base of the eyelashes and the lid margin appears injected.

This is the typical appearance of blepharitis.
questions.hint: Chronic inflammation and scaling at the eyelid margins associated with eye irritation and visual abnormalities is consistent with a diagnosis of blepharitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of a 1-day history of painful swelling of her left periorbital region. Yesterday morning, she woke up with a tender, warm, soft lump on the left eyelid. Eye movement does not worsen the pain. Physical examination shows redness and swelling of the left upper eyelid that involves the hair follicles. Upon palpation, the swelling drains purulent fluid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A hordeolum is an acute, purulent inflammation of the eyelid, most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus, which comes in two forms. An external hordeolum or stye, as seen in this patient, arises from the glands of Moll or glands of Zeis. An internal hordeolum (less common) is an inflammation of a meibomian gland, most typically at the palpebral conjunctiva. The appearance of an acute-onset, painful, erythematous, and purulent nodule can be worrying to patients, but the condition typically resolves after 1–2 weeks. Treatment includes application of warm compresses. Incision and curettage are only indicated in the case of nonresponse to conservative therapy or severe symptoms.

Key learning point: A hordeolum (stye) is an acute, painful, erythematous, and purulent nodule of the eyelid, most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus infection of eyelash follicles or associated glands.
Image Description:

Right eye (temporal view)

There is erythema and swelling of the upper eyelid. A yellow pus point is visible at the lid margin near the base of the eyelash follicle.

This is the typical appearance of an external hordeolum.

B) INCORRECT:

Dacryocystitis manifests with erythema, edema, warmth, purulent drainage, and significant pain. However, unlike the lump in this patient, which arises from the upper eyelid, dacryocystitis arises from the lacrimal sac, which is located below the medial canthus of the eye.
Image Description:

The right lacrimal sac region shows an elevated pus point and swelling. The lacrimal abscess developed due to dacryocystitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Blepharitis usually manifests with red and swollen eyelids and crusty, scaly plaques or oily deposits on the eyelid margins. It typically causes chronic, recurrent symptoms of inflammation of bilateral eyelids (pain, pruritus) and irritation of the eyes (excessive tearing, foreign body sensation). In contrast, this patient has acute-onset, unilateral symptoms. Also, she has no plaques, and there is no report of excessive tearing or foreign body sensation.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography

There is crusting at the base of the eyelashes and the lid margin appears injected.

This is the typical appearance of blepharitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Xanthelasmas are cholesterol-filled, soft, yellow plaques that most commonly appear on the medial aspects of the eyelids in patients with diabetes mellitus or hyperlipoproteinemia. Unlike this patient's condition, xanthelasmas are not purulent and do not cause pain or erythema.
Image Description:

There are well demarcated, yellow plaques on the medial aspect of the bilateral eyelids, which is consistent with xanthelasma.

Xanthelasma consists of cutaneous lipid deposits and is a common finding in patients with hypercholesterolemia.

E) INCORRECT:

A chalazion is a slowly progressing, firm, rubbery, and nonpurulent nodule on the eyelid. Unlike this patient's acutely painful lesion, a chalazion is classically a nontender, chronic lesion that may result in a sensation of heaviness of the eyelid.
Image Description:

Left eye with ectropionized lower eyelid

A localized, nodular swelling is visible on the medial portion of the ectropionized lower eyelid. Both bulbar and tarsal conjunctiva are hyperemic.

This is the typical appearance of a chalazion.
questions.hint: This patient has a condition that exclusively affects the eyelids. More specifically, it affects the tear glands or the hair follicles of the eyelashes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-day history of pain and swelling in her right eye. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms consistently. A photograph of the right eye is shown. The right eyelid is mildly tender on palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics, such as gentamicin, can be considered in patients with frequent hordeola or severe symptoms (e.g., concurrent blepharoconjunctivitis), neither of which are reported here. Therefore, a different, first-line treatment should be tried in this patient before considering topical antibiotics.

Excisional biopsy is performed in cases of recurrent or persistent chalazion to rule out malignancy (e.g., sebaceous carcinoma). This patient's clinical presentation is diagnostic of a hordeolum; therefore, there is no indication for an excisional biopsy.

A localized, nodular swelling is visible on the medial portion of the ectropionized lower eyelid. Both bulbar and tarsal conjunctiva are hyperemic.

This is the typical appearance of a chalazion.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage can be used in the treatment of hordeolum manifesting with severe symptoms (e.g., large hordeolum) or not showing any response to medical management within 1–2 weeks of therapy. E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhea. He does not have any discharge, severe eyelid pain, or decreased vision but notes some eye irritation. A photograph of the right eyelid is shown. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A) INCORRECT:

A hordeolum represents an acute inflammation and infection of a meibomian gland at the lid margin. It appears as a red, tender bump that may spontaneously leak purulent discharge. Topical antibiotics may also be used.
Image Description:

Right eye

There is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.

This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

B) INCORRECT:

Sebaceous carcinomas and basal-cell carcinomas of the eyelid appear as firm, painless masses on the eyelid. Sebaceous carcinomas tend to be indurated or ulcerated; basal-cell carcinomas tend to have surface telangiectasias and an irregular surface texture.

C) INCORRECT:

Sebaceous carcinomas and basal-cell carcinomas of the eyelid appear as firm, painless masses on the eyelid. Sebaceous carcinomas tend to be indurated or ulcerated; basal-cell carcinomas tend to have surface telangiectasias and an irregular surface texture.

D) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum of the eyelid is characterized by multiple small, dome-shaped nodules, with umbilicated centers, located at the eyelid margin.

E) CORRECT:

A chalazion is a lipogranuloma resulting from a chronically obstructed meibomian gland. It appears as a subacute, usually nontender mass that is minimally erythematous and initially infected. In contrast, a hordeolum represents an acute inflammation and infection of a meibomian gland at the lid margin. It appears as a red, tender bump that may spontaneously leak purulent discharge. If unresolved, an acute internal hordeolum can become chronic or develop into a chalazion.

Chalazia and hordeola are both treated with warm compresses to encourage drainage of the obstructed gland. Topical antibiotics may also be used. Chalazia that do not resolve with conservative therapy can be injected with glucocorticoids or surgically excised.

Key learning point: A subacute, nontender eyelid mass that results from a chronically inflamed meibomian gland is a chalazion.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to your clinic by her mother because of a 1-day history of painful swelling in the left periorbital region. Yesterday morning, she awoke with a tender, warm, soft lump on her left eyelid. Eye movement does not worsen the pain. On examination, there is redness and swelling of the left upper eyelid involving the hair follicles. Palpation of the swelling results in drainage of purulent fluid. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Xanthelasmas are cholesterol-filled, soft, yellow plaques that most commonly appear on the medial aspects of the eyelids in patients with diabetes mellitus or hyperlipoproteinemia. Unlike this patient's condition, xanthelasmas are not purulent and do not cause pain or erythema.

B) INCORRECT:

Blepharitis usually manifests with red and swollen eyelids and crusty, scaly plaques or oily deposits on the eyelid margins. It typically causes chronic, recurrent symptoms of inflammation of bilateral eyelids (pain, pruritus) and irritation of the eyes (excessive tearing, foreign body sensation). In contrast, this patient has acute-onset, unilateral symptoms. Also, she has no plaques, and there is no report of excessive tearing or foreign body sensation.

C) INCORRECT:

Dacryocystitis manifests with erythema, edema, warmth, purulent drainage, and significant pain. However, unlike the lump in this patient, which arises from the upper eyelid, dacryocystitis arises from the lacrimal sac, which is located below the medial canthus of the eye.

D) INCORRECT:

A chalazion is a slowly progressing, firm, rubbery, and nonpurulent nodule on the eyelid. Unlike this patient's acutely painful lesion, a chalazion is classically a nontender, chronic lesion that may result in a sensation of heaviness of the eyelid.

E) CORRECT:

A hordeolum is an acute, purulent inflammation of the eyelid, most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus, which comes in two forms. An external hordeolum or stye, as seen in this patient, arises from the glands of Moll or glands of Zeis. An internal hordeolum (less common) is an inflammation of a meibomian gland, most typically at the palpebral conjunctiva. The appearance of an acute-onset, painful, erythematous, and purulent nodule can be worrying to patients, but the condition typically resolves after 1–2 weeks. Treatment includes application of warm compresses. Incision and curettage are only indicated in the case of nonresponse to conservative therapy or severe symptoms.

Key learning point: A hordeolum (stye) is an acute, painful, purulent inflammation of the eyelid, most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus, and typically resolves with warm compresses.
Image Description:

Right eye (temporal view)

There is erythema and swelling of the upper eyelid. A yellow pus point is visible at the lid margin near the base of the eyelash follicle.

This is the typical appearance of an external hordeolum.
questions.hint: This patient has a condition that exclusively affects the eyelids. More specifically, it affects the tear glands or the hair follicles of the eyelashes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-week history of burning, itching eyes, and a sensation of foreign-body irritation. She reports that her symptoms worsen in dry weather. She has a history of recurrent chalazia on her upper eyelids. On examination, her visual acuity is 20/20 in each eye. Which one of the following examination findings would support the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injected scleral vessels are a sign of scleritis, which is typically characterized by unilateral achy pain with tenderness to the touch.

B) CORRECT:

Typical eye findings with blepharitis include crusting at the base of the eyelashes and ocular injection. Blepharitis can range from asymptomatic to severe, with symptoms including burning, itching, foreign-body sensation, dryness, and mucous discharge. Chronic inflammation may lead to obstruction of the oil glands causing a stye or chalazion. Blepharitis is treated with warm compresses, eyelid scrubs with baby shampoo, and preservative-free artificial tears.

Key learning point: In addition to inflammation of the eyelids, a classic feature of blepharitis is crusting of the eyelashes.

C) INCORRECT:

A corneal epithelial defect is a corneal abrasion, which usually has a precipitating factor, such as trauma.

D) INCORRECT:

Conjunctival follicles are pale, dome-shaped elevations of conjunctiva most commonly caused by infections, particularly with adenoviruses (pink eye).

E) INCORRECT:

Ciliary flush is characteristic of anterior uveitis, in which patients also have symptoms of photophobia and achy pain due to inflammation within the iris and ciliary body.
questions.hint: The combination of ocular-surface symptoms (foreign-body sensation and burning) and recurrent chalazia is suggestive of blepharitis (chronic inflammation of the eyelids).

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to your clinic with a bump on his right lower eyelid that he has noticed for 3 months. He reports that it has not changed in size recently. He does not have any discharge, severe eyelid pain, or decreased vision, but notes some eye irritation. A photograph of the right eyelid is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sebaceous carcinomas and basal-cell carcinomas of the eyelid appear as firm, painless masses on the eyelid. Sebaceous carcinomas tend to be indurated or ulcerated; basal-cell carcinomas tend to have surface telangiectasias and an irregular surface texture.

B) INCORRECT:

Sebaceous carcinomas and basal-cell carcinomas of the eyelid appear as firm, painless masses on the eyelid. Sebaceous carcinomas tend to be indurated or ulcerated; basal-cell carcinomas tend to have surface telangiectasias and an irregular surface texture.

C) INCORRECT:

A hordeolum represents an acute inflammation and infection of a meibomian gland at the lid margin. It appears as a red, tender bump that may spontaneously leak purulent discharge. If unresolved, an acute internal hordeolum can become chronic or develop into a chalazion. Hordeola are treated with warm compresses to encourage drainage of the obstructed gland. Topical antibiotics may also be used.

D) CORRECT:

A chalazion is a lipogranuloma resulting from a chronically obstructed meibomian gland. It appears as a subacute, usually nontender mass that is minimally erythematous and initially infected. In contrast, a hordeolum represents an acute inflammation and infection of a meibomian gland at the lid margin. It appears as a red, tender bump that may spontaneously leak purulent discharge. If unresolved, an acute internal hordeolum can become chronic or develop into a chalazion.

Chalazia and hordeola are both treated with warm compresses to encourage drainage of the obstructed gland. Topical antibiotics may also be used. Chalazia that do not resolve with conservative therapy can be injected with glucocorticoids or surgically excised.

Key learning point: A subacute, nontender eyelid mass that results from a chronically inflamed meibomian gland is a chalazion.

E) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum of the eyelid is characterized by multiple small, dome-shaped nodules, with umbilicated centers, located at the eyelid margin.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of blurred vision upon awakening. She reports that when she wakes up in the morning, both eyelids are irritated, sore, and covered with a dry crust. On examination, both eyes have erythema and irritation at the superior lid margin, with flakes at the base of the lashes. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin can be helpful in the treatment of blepharitis and in the perioperative period for patients undergoing eye surgery. It is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that reduces the bacterial load around the eyelids, lashes, and conjunctiva. However, it is not an appropriate first-line therapy for mild blepharitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Culture and gram stain can be useful in diagnosing gonococcal conjunctivitis. Gonococcal conjunctivitis is characterized by acute conjunctival hyperemia, purulent discharge, and periorbital swelling. Her symptoms are not consistent with gonococcal infection and a culture would not be helpful.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics, such as doxycycline, can be used in the treatment of severe or treatment-refractory blepharitis. It is not used as first-line treatment, especially for a mild presentation such as this one, because of the risk of adverse events, such as photosensitivity, gastrointestinal distress, and interference with oral contraceptives.

D) INCORRECT:

A topical glucocorticoid, such as triamcinolone, is used as an agent of last resort for treating severe, treatment-refractory blepharitis. Topical steroids should be used carefully in this situation given the side effect profile, and patients should be evaluated by an ophthalmologist prior to initiation. This patient has a mild presentation and so a different management approach is more appropriate.

E) CORRECT:

Warm compresses, lid massage, and gentle lid cleansing are the cornerstones of therapy for mild blepharitis. As blepharitis is often a chronic condition with discrete episodes, ongoing lid hygiene is important in minimizing the frequency and intensity of flares.

Key learning point: Initial management of mild blepharitis involves regular lid hygiene with warm compresses and gentle cleansing to reduce symptoms and prevent recurrences.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography

There is crusting at the base of the eyelashes and the lid margin appears injected.

This is the typical appearance of blepharitis.
questions.hint: Chronic inflammation and scaling at the eyelid margins associated with eye irritation and visual abnormalities is consistent with a diagnosis of blepharitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-day history of pain and swelling in her right eye. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms consistently. A photograph of the right eye is provided. The right eyelid is mildly tender on palpation. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A hordeolum is an acute purulent inflammation of the eyelid, most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus, that occurs in two forms. This patient has an internal hordeolum, which typically arises at the palpebral conjunctiva. External hordeolum is more common and typically arises at the lid margin. For both types of hordeolum, the first step in management is the application of warm compresses and gentle massage to promote drainage of the blocked gland. Additionally, eyelid margin hygiene (i.e., debris removal with a clean cotton swab) should be maintained. If the patient has severe symptoms or does not respond to conservative treatment after 1–2 weeks, an ophthalmologist should be consulted for incision and curettage. Treatment with topical corticosteroids and antimicrobials (e.g., erythromycin, sulfacetamide) or systemic antibiotics (e.g., oral cephalexin) may be necessary in these cases.

Key learning point: The initial management of a hordeolum (stye) is the application of warm compresses and gentle eyelid hygiene.

B) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy is performed in cases of recurrent or persistent chalazion to rule out malignancy (e.g., sebaceous carcinoma). Although chalazia can resemble hordeola in appearance, they are slow-growing and not associated with signs of inflammation (e.g., erythema, pain). This patient's clinical presentation is diagnostic of a hordeolum; therefore, there is no indication for an excisional biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhea. Neisserial conjunctivitis typically occurs in neonates; it can rarely occur in young, sexually active adults, but the presentation is usually more severe with marked eyelid swelling, profuse purulent discharge, and hyperemic conjunctivae. Systemic antibiotic therapy (e.g., oral cephalexin) may be indicated in persistent or severe hordeolum associated with complications (e.g., preseptal cellulitis) if conservative measures have been exhausted.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage can be used in the treatment of hordeolum manifesting with severe symptoms (e.g., large hordeolum) or not showing any response to medical management within 1–2 weeks of therapy. As this patient presents with mild symptoms for 1 day only, a different, first-line treatment should be tried before considering incision and drainage.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics, such as erythromycin, can be considered in patients with frequent hordeola or severe symptoms (e.g., concurrent blepharoconjunctivitis), neither of which is reported here. A different first-line treatment should be tried in this patient before considering topical antibiotics.
questions.hint: An acute, painful, erythematous nodule of the eyelid, in conjunction with this patient's otherwise unremarkable clinical presentation, is consistent with hordeolum (stye).
